texts.shortText: Very distinctive colonial species in which the thick, freshy, oval, pink tunic projects vertically from the rock surface and is supported on a short flexible stalk or peduncle. The small zooids are darker pink and each is enclosed is a small capsule embedded in the tunic. Each zooid is about 6 mm long and has a pair of closely-adjacent siphons. Pieces of colony are often used as cloaks by dromid crabs.
Colonies up to about 200 mm in height.

Global: South Africa (and possibly Falkland Islands).

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to East London.

A fairy common and unusual species with a distinct paddle-like appearance that often causes interest when specimens are cast up in large numbers after storms. Pieces of colony are also often used a ‘cloaks’ by dromid crabs such as Pseudodromia latens (see Fig. 57.4 in Two Oceans book).

The structure of the outer test is interesting as it is composed of cellulose, a material normally associated with plants and found only in this group of animals. Cellulose may be a good choice for a protective coasting, as few animals have enzymes capable of digesting this material!

All ascidians are filter feeder, drawing seawater in thought the inhalant siphon and filtering this though a net of mucous, which is continuously generated and passed across the mesh-like walls of the pharynx, before being rolled up and into a threadlike cord and transported to the oesophagus.

Colonies expanded via asexual reproduction (budding of existing zooids), but new ones are established only by broadcast spawning. Eggs and sperm are released into the water, where fertilization takes place and the unusual tadpole larvae develop. Ascidian larvae are famous for revealing the chordate affinities of the group, which are hard to appreciate by examining the rather degenerate-looking sedentary adults! The larvae have a distinct tail and notocord (primitive ‘backbone’) and swim actively. When they are ready to settle they attach themselves to the substratum with adhesive papillae on the head and resorb the tail and notochord, effectively rotating the body 180 degrees so that the ‘mouth’ or inhalant siphon now points upwards.

Entire colonies are unmistakable. The detailed taxonomy of the group is confused though (see Monniot reference below) and is it seems likely that samples reported from Falklands and KwaZulu-Natal may represent other similar species.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 248).

Monniot, C, Monniot, F, Griffiths, CL & Schleyer, M (2001). South African ascidians. Annals of the South African Museum, 108(1), 1-141 (p. 88).
